Fields.DialogueText: At attention, sailors!
Eugenio di Savoia? What's going on?
I'm just preparing the crew for inspection, Capitano.
But the Admiral isn't arriving for quite a while.
A military's effectiveness begins with discipline.

Fields.MenuText: But I think you might be taking it too far right now.
I appreciate your commitment to discipline, Eugenio di Savoia.
Don't you think this might hurt morale?

Fields.DialogueText: The crew respects me for my demands, Capitano.
Grazie, Capitano. I'm glad we see eye to eye.
No. Morale comes from the knowledge that a soldier is all he or she can be.
Discipline is important. Through it we shall make Italy proud tomorrow during the fleet inspection.
*ALARM*
It looks like it's time right now to put that discipline to the test.
@BATTLE
Battle stations! Enemy spottted to the west!
@BATTLE
Eugenio di Savoia!
Sì, Capitano?
Are you all right?
Sì. I took a glancing hit to the starboard bow, but I think it should buff out.
I'm impressed. You remained remarkably calm during that battle, Eugenio di Savoia, even when we were under heavy fire.
It is only my duty.

Fields.MenuText: And you do it well.
Are you always like this?
Not everyone would see it that way.

Fields.DialogueText: Everyone here did their duty today.
Sì.
Not everyone is fit to fly the Italian flag, either.
Well, let's see to your repairs.
Are you excited, Eugenio di Savoia? Inspection time is here.
I am! The crew has been practicing their drills, and I, for one, am greatly looking forward to meeting the Admiral.
Speaking of which, here he is.
Admiral on deck!
That's the Admiral!?
What were you expecting?
Someone a little more... military-looking.
Well, he does have lots of medals.
Yes, and plenty of space to display them.

Fields.MenuText: Eugenio di Savoia!
Ha ha, you're right. He looks like a bowl of jelly.
Best not let him hear you say that.

Fields.DialogueText: Did I say that?
Well, I wouldn't go that far.
You're probably correct.
*ALARM*
It looks like inspection will have to wait. We have Morganas to fight!
@BATTLE
She really knows how to handle her own in battle!
@BATTLE
Good work, Capitano. A truly remarkable display of courage and discipline.
Thank you, Admiral, but you really have Eugenio di Savoia to thank. She was the one who trained the crew.
Ah, yes, the Belle! You were truly magnificent!

Fields.MenuText: Are you all right?
Aren't you going to say something?
I think you need some rest, Eugenio di Savoia.

Fields.DialogueText: Perfect, Capitano. Grazie, Ammiraglio.
Grazie, Ammiraglio.
... You might be right. Grazie, Ammiraglio.
Hm. Well, regardless, we wouldn't stand a chance against these Morganas without Belles like you, Eugenio di Savoia.
Mind telling me what that was all about?
He didn't even see the battle. He spent it all below deck.
He went white as a sheet when the Morganas showed up.
Capitano, how did he become an ammiraglio?
He... has friends in high places.
I see.
Perhaps he would be better off in those high places.
Get ready to see it again, Admiral.
Well, Eugenio di Savoia, the Admiral's gone, off to continue the inspection of the Protection Force.
Good riddance.

Fields.MenuText: I'm surprised at your venom, Eugenio di Savoia. What happened to discipline? To chain of command?
Honestly, I'm glad to be rid of him as well.
That's your superior officer you're talking about.

Fields.DialogueText: A leader needs to hold his or her people's respect. That's the only way it works.
At least now we can focus on the Morganas.
No, that's your superior officer. I'm a ship.
Then I suppose you don't want this medal...
Medal?
For the inspection. Apparently you have one of the finest crews the Admiral's seen.
I... if it's from him, I don't want it.
It's a real medal, Eugenio di Savoia, even if he isn't a real Admiral.
Still, I prefer to earn medals in battle, not on parade.
*ALARM*
Well, here's your chance.
@BATTLE
You're looking thoughtful today, Eugenio di Savoia.
Yes, I've been thinking about what the Ammiraglio said.
The Admiral? I thought you didn't like him.
I don't, but he still made a good point. What would you do without us Belles around? What if something happened to us?

Fields.MenuText: I suppose our fight would be harder.
Are you questioning my ability to lead?
I think... I'd rather not think about that.

Fields.DialogueText: I hope that's all, Capitano.
No! Never.
And yet it could happen, couldn't it?
What are you getting at, Eugenio di Savoia?
Nothing, Capitano. I'm just thinking out loud.
*ALARM*
We'll talk about this later.
@BATTLE
Oh, there you are, Eugenio di Savoia. What are you reading?
A Farewell to Arms. It's quite good.

Fields.MenuText: Ah, Hemingway! Truly a master of modern literature.
I didn't know you were so well-read, Eugenio di Savoia.
Isn't that book a little anti-war?

Fields.DialogueText: Sì, though I think I like Faulkner better.
Is that surprising to you?
Maybe it is, but is that so bad?
It's surprisingly hard to predict just what you Belles will get up to.
Before the war, I traveled the globe with my sister. I would like to return to that when this is all over. But now is not the time for that.
When it is time to fight, we must fight. We must fight as hard as we can, for with victory will come peace.
*ALARM*
Speaking of fighting...
@BATTLE
Eugenio di Savoia?
Hm?
Oh, there you are. What are you doing in here? You're usually out on the deck, supervising the crew.
I'm writing a letter to an old friend.

Fields.MenuText: I didn't know you had any friends.
What's it about?
Is that my stationery?

Fields.DialogueText: Very funny, Capitano.
Oh, nothing.
Well, I don't have any of my own, Capitano!
We met in the Caribbean, when I was traveling with my sister. Maybe you'll meet him someday.
Maybe...
*ALARM*
But today we have work to do.
@BATTLE
Oh! Capitano!
Yes, what is it?
My friend wrote back. He would like to come visit!
That's great, but does he know we're in a war zone?
I think that might be why he wants to visit.

Fields.MenuText: Well, that's very strange.
Oh, so he's an adventurous type?
I'm just not sure it will be safe.

Fields.DialogueText: So is he, to be honest.
Sì, I suppose he is, in a way.
I don't think that will dissuade him, Capitano.
There's only one problem... we'd have to pick him up.
Well, where is he?
England.
England. So we just, what, tell Command that we're leaving our war patrol? Just take a little jaunt to England?
*ALARM*
Ugh, we don't have time for this right now.
@BATTLE
I want to accommodate your friend, but we do have some obligations that--
Obligations that assert themselves. I understand how it works, Capitano.
They just do not give up, these Morganas!
@BATTLE
I received an interesting letter from Command today, Savoia.
Is that so, Capitano?
It contained some rather intriguing orders.
It's not every day we get to be intrigued by our orders.
Command wants to send a group of dignitaries to England to discuss the Morgana threat, and we've been ordered to conduct them.
Unambiguous, too. We'd better be about it.

Fields.MenuText: You wouldn't happen to know anything about this, would you, Savoia?
Looks like we're going to be able to pick up your friend after all.
I always figured you for the straightforward type.

Fields.DialogueText: Why, what makes you think that, Capitano?
What a coincidence!
I am! I sent Command a very straightforward request.
But how did you convince them to send us?
Remember, Capitano? I have one of the finest crews in the fleet. There's a medal right here that proves it.
Capitano! I would like to introduce you to my old friend, Professor James Marlborough. He's a professor of Naval Military history at Oxford.
Pleased to meet you, old bean!
Welcome aboard, Professor. Naval history?
That's right! From Salamis to Hampton Roads, I've studied it all.
He's an expert in his field.

Fields.MenuText: Really? What does he think of the Morganas?
I didn't know you were so cultured, Savoia.
Well, I suppose he's going to see some history firsthand.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm sure he doesn't like them.
Well, that's just rude.
Isn't it exciting?
*ALARM*
Hold that thought, Professor. We have some Morganas to handle.
Splendid!
@BATTLE
Fascinating! Simply fascinating!
@BATTLE
That was spectacular! Fascinating to experience such a thing first-hand.
Thank you, Professor.
When Savoia sent me that letter, I knew I couldn't turn down the opportunity to see a Belle in real life. And in battle!
Wait, I thought you two had met?
I'd met him.
But it was before she... ah... awoke, I suppose? The world didn't know about the Belles back then, you see.

Fields.MenuText: I'd be interested to hear more about this.
I'll admit, I'm not too happy about having a civilian on board.
Do you know what caused the Belles to appear, Professor?

Fields.DialogueText: I'll tell you sometime. It's a very beautiful place, the Caribbean.
He won't be here that long, Capitano.
I think that's too recent for him. He is a historian, after all.
Another Morgana task force, Capitano. This looks like it could be a tough battle...
@BATTLE
What a battle! I should really write a paper on this.
Thanks, Professor.
To be honest, I'm not sure I really have that much to teach you.
Er...
What was that about teaching us?
Oh, in her letter, Savoia mentioned you wanted some instruction on naval history. Tactics, great battles, things like that.
Did she now?
Now, Capitano...

Fields.MenuText: I knew there was something fishy about this!
Do you really doubt me that much?
I don't see how this would even be relevant.

Fields.DialogueText: There's nothing fishy going on!
I don't doubt your abilities, Capitano. I just want to make sure you and the crew are safe without me.
You would be surprised.
I don't like this.
Nonsense! It will be fun! Now, where's my tricorn...
Without you, Savoia? I...
... And so Nelson deployed his ships in a column, such that they would split the joint Spanish and French armada right down the middle. Now, this was...
Psst! Savoia... Savoia, I will never forgive you for this.
Hush, Capitano. Just give him a chance.

Fields.MenuText: He's been talking about Trafalgar for two hours.

Fields.DialogueText: Ah... Captain? Are you listening?
I'm sorry, but I think you're over-emphasizing the relevance. This battle happened over a century ago, and it was against a very different enemy in very different conditions.
And yet the tactics employed were still used to great success in the Russo-Japanese war.

Fields.MenuText: Which was still forty years ago!
Right. Well, that's food for thought, but I must be off. I have a ship to run.
I will never forgive you for this, Savoia.

Fields.DialogueText: The fundamentals stay the same.
The ship says stay.
It's for your own good.
Now, as I was saying. Nelson's flagship, HMS Victory, was...
*ALARM*
Oh, thank God.
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: None of this is new to me. I've written about it myself.
I joined the Navy to get away from classrooms. You know that, right?

Fields.DialogueText: Welcome back to school, Capitano.
I'm actually enjoying this. You should try to do the same.
And yet I don't remember anybody calling you "Professor," right?
Good day, Captain!
No.
Are you ready for today's...
No.
Captain, I'm starting to think I'm not welcome here.

Fields.MenuText: I can't imagine what gave you that idea.
Good. Because you're not.
I was thinking the same thing, Professor.

Fields.DialogueText: Sarcasm doesn't suit you, Capitano.
Ignore the Capitano, Professor. The last few battles must have been stressful, that's all.
I don't know what you're talking about, Capitano!
Now, I wanted to talk to you about something. I had an idea about...
If I say yes, will you stop talking to me?
I... well, yes, I suppose...
*ALARM*
We'll talk after this. Excuse me.
@BATTLE
I look like an idiot.
No, you look like a leader!
An obsolete leader.
Nelson dressed like that, and he was one of the most accomplished naval commanders in history.
He also lost an arm, an eye, and died to a sniper. Maybe he wouldn't have been hurt so much if he didn't dress like a blue Christmas tree.
Hahaha...

Fields.MenuText: Are you... laughing?
Great. That's what I need now. My own ship making fun of me.
This is your fault. You did this.

Fields.DialogueText: Is the concept so alien to you?
Oh, calm down.
You look fine!
I'm not going into battle like this.
*ALARM*
Au contraire, my friend!
Damn.
@BATTLE
You look happy today, Capitano.
I just received a message from Command.
Oh?
The Morgana talks in England are over. They want us to return and pick up the dignitaries to take them home.
Is that so?
Your friend is going back.
He hasn't been that bad.
Ah! There you are! I have a marvelous sea shanty for you, Captain! Your crew will love it!

Fields.MenuText: He made me wear brocade, Savoia. I don't even know what that is.
I haven't learned a thing from him, and I still don't understand what made you think I would.
Sea shanties, Savoia. Sea shanties.

Fields.DialogueText: Point taken.
I just thought you could use a good foundation. But, you're right.
Okay, okay, fair enough.
Sorry, Professor. No sea shanties today.
Morganas sighted!
Not even one?
@BATTLE
Well, the professor's back home, safe and sound.
Unfortunately.
I thought you wanted him gone?
I meant the safe and sound part.
Capitano!
I'm kidding.

Fields.MenuText: Sometimes he got in the way, but I suppose his lessons were interesting, in their own way.
I'm just glad to move on from this nonsense.
I hope you have more confidence in me now, Savoia.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm glad you think so, Capitano.
I will admit, he did start to get tiresome.
Always, Capitano.
*ALARM*
Work never ends. Shall we?
@BATTLE
Morgana patrol crossing our path, Capitano.
@BATTLE
Well, things should be quiet for a while now.
Have I ever told you about my voyage with my sister, Emanuele Filiberto Duca d'Aosta?
Not really, Savoia. Only bits and pieces.
It was wonderful. In the Caribbean, the water is this pale blue, like crystal. You can see right into it, where the fish and the children swim.
Islands dot the landscape. It's not like the open ocean. Not cold and boring, endless waves of gunmetal gray stretching over the horizon.
In the Caribbean, warm waters lap against you, and these beautiful islands are everywhere, with beautiful people. Warm-hearted, with good food, too.

Fields.MenuText: I think I'd like to visit this place someday.
That was lovely, Savoia.
It's like I'm there!

Fields.DialogueText: You can come with my sister and me.
Grazie. I really do miss it.
If only, Capitano.
That's why it's so important that we defeat the Morganas. For the peaceful islands of the Caribbean.
Savoia.
Hello, Capitano! Wait... what is that look on your face all about?
Why was there an almanac of naval history on my desk?
I just thought you could use some reading, Capitano.

Fields.MenuText: Thanks, but I have enough to do. Like commanding this ship.

Fields.DialogueText: We can always find time for a little reading, Capitano.
Savoia, do we need to have a talk?
I don't doubt your abilities, but you should understand my point of view.
A ship without a Belle is no ship at all?
Sì, Capitano. And this Belle will do her part to make the ship the best it can be.
*ALARM*
We'll talk later.
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: I just wish you would have more faith in me.
I hope you didn't pay too much for it.

Fields.DialogueText: I do have faith in you, Capitano!
How much is too much?
This might be our most heated battle to date, Capitano.
@BATTLE
Okay, let's talk, Savoia.
Capitano, I don't doubt your leadership. You should stop thinking of it that way.
You keep saying that.
But we're in a war. The crew looks up to me, and I've spent so long training them. What will they do without me, if we're separated for some reason?

Fields.MenuText: Aren't you being a little premature with your concerns?
I understand. Train them well, and hope your training is good enough to stick.
That's just the risk of being a leader.

Fields.DialogueText: Maybe I am, Capitano. I don't know.
Exactly. I want to give them their best chances, even if something were to happen to me.
And I'm working to manage that risk, Capitano.
Savoia, I promise you I'll always help you shoulder the burdens of leadership. You're not alone in this.
Grazie, Capitano. That's what I needed to know.
One way to find out. Battle stations, Savoia.
What's that smell?
Capitano! You're just in time!
What is all this, Savoia?
I thought I would lift everyone's spirits and make some Caribbean cook-up. A secret recipe concocted by me and my sister.

Fields.MenuText: You never cease to surprise me, Savoia.
That really does smell good.
I wasn't hungry until now.

Fields.DialogueText: I'll choose to take that as a compliment.
Just wait until you taste it!
I'm glad that changed.
What's the occasion?
Well, I've been thinking about my sister lately, and the Caribbean. The memories are so uplifting, I thought I would share with you and the crew.
Thoughtful of you, Savoia.
*ALARM*
Damn. You don't think the Morganas will wait, do you?
@BATTLE
These battles are getting tougher.
Sì, but we are, too. We'll fight on! Hey, whoa, sailor, button up your shirt!
Oh! Yes, ma'am...
Where was I? Oh, yes. We'll fight on, no matter how hard the battles are.
Of course.
I've always held people to a certain standard, Capitano. You. The crew. Maybe I haven't made a lot of friends that way. But it means we'll be ready.

Fields.MenuText: Together, we can win.
I've always respected your commitment.
Friends are important, but so is respect.

Fields.DialogueText: I know it.
Grazie, Capitano.
I'll always take admiration over affection.
Morganas!
@BATTLE
There is heavy Morgana activity in the area, Captain.
@BATTLE
This is it, Savoia. We're closing in on a hub of Morgana activity in the area.
I'm ready, Capitano.
I don't know what we'll find, but it won't be pretty. And it won't be easy.
The crew has trained for this. I'm ready. And I know you're ready, too.

Fields.MenuText: Thank you, Savoia.
No advice? No almanac?
Finally.

Fields.DialogueText: Of course.
What can I say? You've graduated.
No need to be that way, Capitano.
Do you have our next course, Savoia?
Sì, Capitano. I'll give the decks a quick inspection while we transit.
And we're ready for it. All hands to battle stations!
Sì, Capitano, and the charts are ready for your review.
Steady as she goes. And Savoia? I know the crew is in good shape for this, thanks to you.
You know what that formation of Morganas means, Capitano?
@BATTLE
Savoia! Savoia! Are you okay?
Whew! Sì, sì... I am fine.
That battle was...
Agreed. I've seen easier fights, too...
We made it, though. You'll still get to see your sister, again.
Yes... Capitano?
Yes?
Sorry for doubting you before.
I thought you said...
I was so worried about what would happen without my leadership if anything ever happened to me, I forgot that I wasn't the only strong leader here.
That might be the nicest thing you've ever said to me.
You'll do a fine job with this ship. Please excuse me while I check on the crew.
If anything happened to Eugenio di Savoia...

Fields.MenuText: I'd fight even harder, to make her proud!
I'm not sure what I'd do...

Fields.DialogueText: I think your professor friend would say that looks like a prepared line.
Ha! Maybe a lecture or two did take root, Capitano! I agree with your tactical assessment. The Morganas look just as ready for us as we are for them. No matter - we'll win.
